title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement andrewbruce.himni@gmail.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

what: Getting Started with Transparency in Coverage Files
title: defogger
text: path analyzing health insurance company’s Transparency Coverage (TiC) files begins public TiC site. Centene Corporation’s located . begin, simply right-click copy one links’ URL addresses:  assign object R:  ’s important note Table Contents (TOC) file. TOC files ’ll start contain top-level information plan’s name, id, market (individual group), URL address plan’s -network negotiated rates --network allowable amounts.  can retrieve parse TOC file defog_toc() function:  returns data frame containing 2,598 rows , simplicity’s sake, ’ve limited first 10 rows:

title: defogger
text: Next ’ll download one --network (OON) files, also known “allowed amounts” files. results , can filter rate_type column out_of_network make sure remove duplicate URLs {dplyr}’s distinct() function:   Next, plug URL object defog_oon() function retrieve file:  , ’ve limited output first ten rows demonstration purposes, gives good idea OON file contains. Next, ’ll retrieve -network file.
code: centene_oon_CA <- centene_toc |>    dplyr::filter(rate_type == "out_of_network") |>    dplyr::select(location) |>    dplyr::distinct() |>    tibble::deframe()  centene_oon_CA #> [1] "http://centene.com/content/dam/centene/Centene%20Corporate/json/DOCUMENT/2022-06-29_centene-management-company-llc_ambetter-ca_allowed-amounts.json" centene_oon_CA_file <- defog_oon(centene_oon_CA) |>    dplyr::slice_head(n = 10)

title: defogger
text: workflow -network (INN) file much , though output different, thus need different function. time, filter rate_type column in_network, making sure remove duplicate URLs:   plug URL object defog_inn() function:   output shows first ten rows 141,580 total. , without doubt, embarassment riches us healthcare data analytics. However, absent data points enable us expand analysis even . NPPES NPI Registry API comes handy.
code: centene_inn_CA <- centene_toc |>    dplyr::filter(rate_type == "in_network") |>    dplyr::select(location) |>    dplyr::distinct() |>    tibble::deframe()  centene_inn_CA #> [1] "http://centene.com/content/dam/centene/Centene%20Corporate/json/DOCUMENT/2022-06-29_centene-management-company-llc_ambetter-ca_in-network.json" centene_inn_CA_file <- defog_inn(centene_inn_CA) |>    dplyr::slice_head(n = 10)

title: defogger
text: Using NPPES Registry Search, can retrieve data provider’s taxonomy, credentials, gender, NPI type, payer-specific identifiers, etc. First, need isolate distinct NPIs OON INN results . five distinct NPIs --network file:   10 distinct NPIs -network file:   Next, pipe {defogger}’s NPPES search function, defog_npi(), via {purrr}’s map_dfr():   gives us two responses NPPES API, can unpack defog_npi_wide() function:    can join two pairs data frames analysis:
code: # OON file centene_oon_npi <- centene_oon_CA_file |>    dplyr::distinct(npi) |>    unlist(use.names = FALSE)  centene_oon_npi #> [1] "1104868124" "1366964330" "1760041487" "1902967557" "1710065933" # INN file centene_inn_npi <- centene_inn_CA_file |>    dplyr::distinct(npi) |>    unlist(use.names = FALSE)  centene_inn_npi #>  [1] "1063050748" "1114499340" "1801314687" "1477217966" "1730531328" #>  [6] "1578813234" "1912103383" "1356852495" "1043304702" "1730294547" # OON file centene_oon_npi_resp <- centene_oon_npi |>    purrr::map_dfr(defog_npi)  centene_oon_npi_resp #> # A tibble: 5 × 4 #>   search     datetime            outcome data_lists    #>   <chr>      <dttm>              <chr>   <list>        #> 1 1104868124 2022-08-27 18:27:59 results <df [1 × 11]> #> 2 1366964330 2022-08-27 18:28:01 results <df [1 × 11]> #> 3 1760041487 2022-08-27 18:28:03 results <df [1 × 11]> #> 4 1902967557 2022-08-27 18:28:05 results <df [1 × 11]> #> 5 1710065933 2022-08-27 18:28:07 results <df [1 × 11]> # INN file centene_inn_npi_resp <- centene_inn_npi |>    purrr::map_dfr(defog_npi)  centene_inn_npi_resp #> # A tibble: 10 × 4 #>    search     datetime            outcome data_lists    #>    <chr>      <dttm>              <chr>   <list>        #>  1 1063050748 2022-08-27 18:28:09 results <df [1 × 11]> #>  2 1114499340 2022-08-27 18:28:11 results <df [1 × 11]> #>  3 1801314687 2022-08-27 18:28:13 results <df [1 × 11]> #>  4 1477217966 2022-08-27 18:28:15 results <df [1 × 11]> #>  5 1730531328 2022-08-27 18:28:18 results <df [1 × 11]> #>  6 1578813234 2022-08-27 18:28:20 results <df [1 × 11]> #>  7 1912103383 2022-08-27 18:28:22 results <df [1 × 11]> #>  8 1356852495 2022-08-27 18:28:24 results <df [1 × 11]> #>  9 1043304702 2022-08-27 18:28:26 results <df [1 × 11]> #> 10 1730294547 2022-08-27 18:28:28 results <df [1 × 11]> # OON file centene_oon_npi_result <- centene_oon_npi_resp |>    dplyr::group_split(search) |>    purrr::map_dfr(defog_npi_wide) # INN file centene_inn_npi_result <- centene_inn_npi_resp |>    dplyr::group_split(search) |>    purrr::map_dfr(defog_npi_wide) # OON file centene_oon_npi_join <- dplyr::full_join(   centene_oon_CA_file,    centene_oon_npi_result,    by = "npi")  centene_oon_npi_join #> # A tibble: 1,320 × 68 #>    name    billi…¹ billi…² billi…³ descr…⁴ ein   servi…⁵ billi…⁶ allow…⁷ bille…⁸ #>    <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr> <chr>   <chr>     <dbl>   <dbl> #>  1 ANES U… CPT     2022    00813   ANESTH… 3301… 24      profes…   1568     4655 #>  2 ANES U… CPT     2022    00813   ANESTH… 3301… 24      profes…   1568     4655 #>  3 NFCT D… HCPCS   2022    0202U   NFCT D… 8220… 20      profes…   9586.   33925 #>  4 NFCT D… HCPCS   2022    0202U   NFCT D… 8220… 20      profes…   9586.   33925 #>  5 ANTIBO… HCPCS   2022    0224U   ANTB S… 4641… 11      profes…   1475.   10500 #>  6 ANTIBO… HCPCS   2022    0224U   ANTB S… 4641… 11      profes…   1475.   10500 #>  7 ANTIBO… HCPCS   2022    0224U   ANTB S… 4641… 11      profes…   1475.   10500 #>  8 ANTIBO… HCPCS   2022    0224U   ANTB S… 4641… 11      profes…   1475.   10500 #>  9 ANTIBO… HCPCS   2022    0224U   ANTB S… 4641… 11      profes…   1475.   10500 #> 10 ANTIBO… HCPCS   2022    0224U   ANTB S… 4641… 11      profes…   1475.   10500 #> # … with 1,310 more rows, 58 more variables: npi <chr>, prov_type <chr>, #> #   id <chr>, first_name <chr>, last_name <chr>, credential <chr>, #> #   sole_proprietor <chr>, gender <chr>, enumeration_date <chr>, #> #   last_updated <chr>, status <chr>, name_prefix <chr>, country_abb <chr>, #> #   country_name <chr>, address_purpose <chr>, address_type <chr>, #> #   address_1 <chr>, address_2 <chr>, city <chr>, state_abb <chr>, #> #   postal_code <chr>, telephone_number <chr>, fax_number <chr>, … # INN file centene_inn_npi_join <- dplyr::full_join(   centene_inn_CA_file,    centene_inn_npi_result,    by = "npi")  centene_inn_npi_join #> # A tibble: 42 × 68 #>    negot…¹ name  billi…² billi…³ billi…⁴ descr…⁵ negot…⁶ negot…⁷ expir…⁸ servi…⁹ #>    <chr>   <chr> <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr>     <dbl> <chr>   <chr>   #>  1 ffs     STRA… CPT     2022    29240   STRAPP… negoti…    27.0 9999-1… 11      #>  2 ffs     STRA… CPT     2022    29240   STRAPP… negoti…    27.0 9999-1… 11      #>  3 ffs     STRA… CPT     2022    29240   STRAPP… negoti…    27.0 9999-1… 11      #>  4 ffs     STRA… CPT     2022    29240   STRAPP… negoti…    27.0 9999-1… 11      #>  5 ffs     STRA… CPT     2022    29240   STRAPP… negoti…    27.0 9999-1… 11      #>  6 ffs     STRA… CPT     2022    29240   STRAPP… negoti…    27.0 9999-1… 11      #>  7 ffs     STRA… CPT     2022    29240   STRAPP… negoti…    27.0 9999-1… 11      #>  8 ffs     STRA… CPT     2022    29240   STRAPP… negoti…    27.0 9999-1… 11      #>  9 ffs     STRA… CPT     2022    29240   STRAPP… negoti…    27.0 9999-1… 11      #> 10 ffs     STRA… CPT     2022    29240   STRAPP… negoti…    27.0 9999-1… 11      #> # … with 32 more rows, 58 more variables: billing_class <chr>, #> #   additional_information <chr>, billing_code_modifier <chr>, npi <chr>, #> #   ein <chr>, prov_type <chr>, id <chr>, first_name <chr>, last_name <chr>, #> #   middle_name <chr>, credential <chr>, sole_proprietor <chr>, gender <chr>, #> #   enumeration_date <chr>, last_updated <chr>, status <chr>, #> #   name_prefix <chr>, country_abb <chr>, country_name <chr>, #> #   address_purpose <chr>, address_type <chr>, address_1 <chr>, city <chr>, …
